awd_titl_txt: Examining Atmospheric and Soil Contamination in Urban Community Gardens
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines the spatial variability of and degree to which atmospheric deposition and/or trace elements in the soil such as arsenic, lead, and others, contaminate soils and vegetables grown in urban community gardens (UCGs). This is of concern because of the potential public health consequences. To date issues of air pollution and soil contamination in UCGs have been understudied, yet UCGs proliferate, and have been lauded as a means of addressing questions of food access and urban sustainability. This investigation advances the understanding of human-environmental interactions and urban political ecology theory as the relationship between air pollution, soils, and gardening in cities needs to be critically evaluated for it to have the positive outcomes generally associated with it. If airborne or soil trace element sources are significant in UCG contamination, then there are potential repercussions in scholarship, policy, and the promotion of urban gardens.  As well as generating new knowledge with public health ramifications about the degree to which there is atmospheric and soil contamination in UCGs, and the contamination pathways, the project includes educational and training opportunities for gardeners, especially participants from under-represented groups. The research also broadens scholarly diversity in urban garden contamination research, and derives societal benefits in raising awareness constructively, spreading effective preventive strategies, and providing data typically beyond gardeners' reach. 

The project's aim is to evaluate the importance of bulk atmospheric deposition compared to other proximate contaminant sources, trace elements in the soil (arsenic, cadmium, mercury, nickel, and lead) and gardening inputs, in urban community gardens. The project systematically assesses the role of atmospheric deposition in relation to trace element contamination in urban community gardens. The investigation takes place in a sample of UCGs in New York City, where the PIs will conduct archival research about the site of each of the UCGs to develop a land-use history. In tandem they will conduct soil surveys to assess the spatial variability of trace element and determine representative soil and crop sampling points. Gardening inputs, vegetables, and soils will be sampled and analyzed for trace element concentrations. Soils will be sampled at multiple depths and analyzed for variables affecting trace element mobility. Part of the vegetables sampled will be grown under row cover to discern variables other than atmospheric deposition. Frisbee-type funnel-bottle bulk collectors will be set up and sampled monthly for a year to gather atmospheric influx data which will be compared to city air quality information. Findings are expected to be transferable to UCGs in other large cities with manufacturing histories and with decades of reliance on fossil-fuel based transport. The techniques developed through this project are also generally applicable to rural areas and small cities. Therefore, although this research project will focus on atmospheric deposition in urban community gardens, the research will provide new insights and approaches for dealing with food production and contamination problems in urban areas in the United States and many other countries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project was about sorting out how much contamination falls on soils and vegetables from the air in urban vegetable gardens compared to other sources of contamination of arsenic, cadmium, lead, mercury, and nickel. Research was done over 2019-2024 in four urban community gardens in Kingston (NY), with three experimental raised beds to grow kale and with samplers for falling dust (bulk atmospheric deposition) in three of the gardens. Pandemic conditions caused extended delays for what was supposed to be a two-year project.

Atmospheric deposition samples were taken monthly for a year and gardens were at least 5 Km apart. There were samples taken of soils within gardening areas and along transects across town. This helped to know about possible contamination from dust generated from within the gardening areas and about how the contamination levels in the gardens compared to the rest of the town. Samples were taken from gardening inputs (mulch, fertiliser, irrigation water, and imported soil) to test for contaminant levels. The experimental beds were set up in such a way as to test how different kinds of growing techniques my affect the amount of contaminant getting onto vegetables and soils from the air. In each garden space, one raised bed had straw mulch on the soil surface and hoop cover, another only mulch, and another had no such covering materials.

Analytical tests revealed frequent cases of contamination above safe levels in soils sampled along the transects and in the garden areas. Inputs and dust samples had negligible amounts of contaminants and there were higher concentrations present in vegetable and soil samples in the experimental beds even if below screening levels. Vegetable contamination was on average higher under hoop covers. This suggests that contamination, even if very low, is likely coming from contaminant-laden particles being loosened and dispersed from within the garden area soils (local redeposition). The hoop covers seem to have a particle trapping and concentration effect.

There had so far been insufficient work done to assess the role of atmospheric deposition in urban garden contamination. No such work has been previously done in Geography that pertains to the biophysical challenges of growing food in cities. Moreover, in general, small town like Kingston tend to be understudied when it comes to issues of urban contamination processes. The results from this study also advance knowledge in branches of Agronomic, Environmental, and Soil Sciences concerned with urban food production, where to date very little has been accomplished to evaluate the role of atmospheric deposition relative to other contaminant sources.

The broader impacts of the project have been to offer educational opportunities rarely or not generally available to undergraduate students and especially to members of the urban gardening community. Another important impact has been to raise awareness of the various sources of contamination and safety measures while demonstrating that legacy soil contamination likely presents the greater challenge to growing food in cities. Finally, in such urban conditions featuring high legacy soil contamination levels and low regional airborne contaminant levels, it is advisable to wear protective clothing, including particle-trapping masks, while working garden soils and, as an additional precaution, avoid hoop covers for vegetable growing. Further study, however, needs to be done to address the latter aspect, as well as to evaluate a probably greater amount of contaminant-laden dust in larger cities with greater industrial emission and vehicular traffic intensities.
